questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with hematemesis and signs of shock. He is diagnosed with acute variceal bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step for this patient?

choices.text: Administer intravenous terlipressin followed by prophylactic intravenous antibiotics
Start intravenous antibiotics and perform urgent endoscopy for band ligation
Administer intravenous vasopressin and initiate fresh frozen plasma transfusion
Begin intravenous corticosteroids and monitor for signs of hepatic encephalopathy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer intravenous terlipressin followed by prophylactic intravenous antibiotics
 

 

Explanation:

In acute variceal bleeding, the initial management should include:

  • Terlipressin: This vasopressin analogue reduces portal hypertension by causing splanchnic vasoconstriction, effectively controlling bleeding from varices.
    • Other vasoactive drugs used in controlling variceal bleeding are Octreotide and Somatostatin.
  • Prophylactic Antibiotics: Administering antibiotics helps prevent infections like spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), which can complicate variceal bleeding.


 

Management of non-bleeding esophageal varices

  • Endoscopic variceal ligation
  • Beta blockers (propanolol, nadolol)

 

Management for bleeding esophageal varices

  • Acute variceal bleeding approach

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse and long-term hypertension presents with hematemesis, abdominal distension, and splenomegaly. He is hypotensive and tachycardic, with elevated liver enzymes, low platelets, and a high INR. Endoscopy reveals esophageal varices. Which of the following most likely explains the development of this condition?

choices.text: Portal venous thrombosis leads to increased collateral circulation
Increased portal blood flow to the liver
Increased portal pressure forcing blood into collateral vessels

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased portal pressure forcing blood into collateral vessels

 

Explanation:

  • The patient appears to have cirrhosis resulting from chronic alcohol use, complicated by the development of esophageal varices.
  • The pathophysiology of esophageal varices in this context is mainly due to portal hypertension associated with cirrhosis.

 

Pathophysiology of esophageal varices in case of cirrhosis:

Investigations:

  • Endoscopy is the most definitive method for diagnosing esophageal varices.
  • Ultrasound and CT/MRI imaging help assess the liver and portal circulation.
  • Portal pressure management to measure wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) by balloon catheter through transjugular route.

 

Portal venous thrombosis leading to increased collateral circulation (Option A):

  • Portal venous thrombosis (PVT) can cause portal hypertension, but in this patient with cirrhosis, the primary cause is liver fibrosis and scarring, leading to increased portal pressure.
  • PVT is less common in this context compared to cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with confusion, disorientation, and asterixis. His family reports increasing drowsiness and difficulty concentrating over the past few days. Investigations reveal normal electrolytes and elevated ammonia levels. What is the most appropriate initial treatment to lower ammonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lactulose

 

Explanation:

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient is likely experiencing hepatic encephalopathy due to elevated ammonia levels associated with alcoholic cirrhosis.
  • The most appropriate initial treatment to lower ammonia is Lactulose.
    • It is a nonabsorbable disaccharide that acidifies the colon, converting ammonia (NH3) into ammonium (NH4+).
    • It aids in removing nitrogenous products from the gut that contribute to encephalopathy and acts as a laxative.

 

Hepatic Encephalopathy

Etiopathogenesis
  • It is a complication of chronic liver disease that leads to impaired brain function as a result of liver failure.
  • It is also called as portosystemic encephalopathy.
  • Ammonia is a gut-derived neurotoxin that is not detoxified into urea and bypasses the liver due to portosystemic shunting and decreased hepatic mass, allowing it to enter the bloodstream and impact the brain.


 

Types

Type A is caused by acute liver failure & cerebral oedema is a common side effect of this type.

Type B is caused by portosystemic shunting (can be due to TIPS also)

Type C is due to chronic liver failure.













 

Clinical manifestations

Grade 0 - alterations are seen in neuropsychological tests, but only minimal symptomatic changes are evident in

  • Short-term memory,
  • Reaction time or
  • Concentration.

Grade 1:

  • Mood changes like anxiety, euphoria;
  • Memory trouble,
  • Trivial lack of awareness,
  • Difficulty with addition and subtraction,
  • Impaired sleep pattern.

Grade 2:

  • Personality changes
  • Lethargy & apathy
  • Behavior changes
  • Dysarthria
  • Disorientation for time

Grade 3:

  • Severe confusion, delirium
  • Disorientation to place
  • Drowsiness
  • Bizarre behavior
  • Asterixis

Grade 4: Coma (total loss of consciousness)

Grade 0,1 are considered convert or minimal hepatic encephalopathy, and grades 2,3,4 are overt hepatic encephalopathy with evident symptoms.

Investigations
  • Psychometric tests
  • Complete clinical evaluation
  • Blood investigations like LFT
  • Doppler ultrasound to evaluate the liver
  • EEG & MRI to assess brain activity

Management
  • Lactulose
  • Rifaximin (Option C) reduces ammonia production; it is an adjunctive therapy in patients who do not tolerate lactulose.
  • Neomycin is an alternative to Rifaximin.
  • Branched-chain amino acids and probiotics
  • Zinc supplementation, used as adjunct therapy (Option B)
  • Restricted protein intake was used in the past but is not commonly used due to its risk of malnutrition outweighs the benefits (Option A)
  • IV hydration is a vital supportive measure

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with decompensated cirrhosis due to hepatitis B presents for evaluation of liver transplantation. All the following are indications for liver transplantation except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Portal vein thrombosis

 

Explanation:

  • Portal vein thrombosis is considered a relative contraindication for liver transplantation as it can affect the viability of the donor's liver and complicate the transplantation process by disrupting the normal blood flow to the liver.
  • It is not an absolute contraindication because portal vein thrombosis can be managed by grafting the donor's portal vein to the recipient's superior mesenteric vein, ensuring adequate venous drainage.

 

Contraindications for Liver Transplantation

Absolute

Relative
  • Active sepsis
  • Uncontrolled extra hepatobiliary infection
  • Life-limiting congenital anomalies
  • Substance abuse
  • Severe cardiopulmonary condition
  • Extra Hepatobiliary malignancy (excluding non-melanoma malignancy skin cancer)
  • Metastasis of Liver Cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma (excluding tumours fitting into the protocol)
  • AIDS
  • Severe systemic disorders
  • Elderly age (> 70)
  • History of extensive hepatobiliary surgery
  • Renal failure, which is not due to liver disease
  • Portal vein thrombosis
  • Severe obesity or malnutrition,
  • History of extrahepatic cancer
  • Non-compliant with medicines
  • Seropositive HIV with CD4 <100/μL
  • Intrahepatic sepsis
  • Increased pulmonary HTN
  • Uncontrolled psychiatric disorder

 

  • Indications of liver transplantation in adults:
    • Autoimmune hepatitis (Option A)
    • Biliary Cirrhosis
    • Caroli’s disease (Option B)
    • Cryptogenic cirrhosis
    • Hepatic vein thrombosis
    • Fulminant hepatitis (Option C)
    • Alcoholic cirrhosis
    • Chronic viral hepatitis
    • Primary hepatocellular malignancies
    • Hepatic adenomas
    • NASH
    • Familial amyloid polyneuropathy
  • HLA matching is not required as the presence of HLA antibodies does not exclude a patient from receiving a transplant.
  • MELD score is used to prioritise patients for liver transplantation based on the severity of their liver disease.
  • Components of UW (University of Wisconsin) solution used for cold ischemia is
    • Lactobionate
    • Raﬃnose
  • pH of the UW solution is around 7.4 at 20°C, with an osmolarity of 320 mmol/kg. The temperature is reduced to 2-6°C prior to its use.
  • Cold ischemic time is up to 20 hours, but the ideal time limit is 12 hours.

 

Lobe preferred in donor for harvesting.

To an adult recipient

Right lobe

To a child recipient

Left lobe or a part of it.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis C presents with worsening abdominal distension, jaundice, and decreased urine output over the past week. He exhibits signs of confusion and ascites resistant to diuretics. Laboratory tests reveal a serum creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL. Given this presentation, which of the following is the most definitive management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Liver transplantation

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's condition is hepatorenal syndrome (HRS).
  • While it is initially managed with albumin infusion and vasoconstrictors (such as terlipressin, octreotide, or midodrine), liver transplantation remains the most definitive and effective treatment for HRS.

 

Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS)

Description

A functional renal failure resulting from advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure without any underlying renal pathology.

Mechanism

  • Vasodilatory prostaglandins (PGE2 and PGI2) enhance renal blood flow and increase glomerular filtration rate to maintain perfusion, while in hepatosplenomegaly:

 
  • The cirrhotic liver produces endothelin-1, resulting in kidney injury, as:

Criteria

  • Refractory ascites (predispose to HRS)
  • Serum creatinine >1.5 mg% (progressive rise)
  • Stop diuretics (causes dehydration)
  • Volume expansion (volume given along with albumin will increase urine output)
  • No shock (but vitals monitoring is required)
  • No nephrotoxic drug exposure
  • No history of parenchymal disease (ruled out by imaging like ultrasound)

Types

Type I HRS or HRS-Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

  • Progressive oliguria (renal function impairment) (Option B)
  • Rapid rise of the serum creatinine
  • Very poor prognosis

Type II HRS or HRS Non-Acute Kidney Injury (NAKI)

  • Associated with refractory ascites
  • Gradual increase in serum creatinine (moderate and stable)
  • Better prognosis.

Clinical features

  • History of chronic liver disease
  • Ascites (refractory or tense).
  • Respiratory distress (shortness of breath)
  • Variceal bleeding (hematemesis)
  • Deranged vitals
  • Decreased urine output or anuria

Management

  • Definitive treatment: Orthoptic liver transplant (OLT)
  • Pharmacological treatment: Following drugs can be used
    • Albumin infusion with vasoconstrictors (terlipressin, octreotide, midodrine) (Option C & D)
    • Norepinephrine can also be used.
    • Hemodialysis is not used mostly as it does not improve the outcome of the condition (Option A)

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with diabetes, obesity, and recent laparoscopic surgery presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, rapid heart rate, extreme fatigue, and worsening abdominal pain. The physician suspects Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) and decides to perform an investigation as part of the diagnostic criteria. Which investigation should be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Complete blood count.

 

Explanation:

A Complete Blood Count (CBC) is essential in evaluating Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) as it helps identify leukocytosis (elevated white blood cell count), which is one of the diagnostic criteria for SIRS.

 

SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome):

  • A sepsis-like condition associated with systemic inflammation that can be triggered by various non-microbial factors (burns, trauma, infections).
  • Criteria for diagnosis: 2 or more of the following components should be present to confirm the diagnosis of SIRS.

Component

Range

Temperature (fever)

Hyperthermia (fever) >38°C (>100.4°F) or

Hypothermia <36°C (<96.8°F)

Leukocyte (white blood cell) count

Leukocytosis >12,000/μL

Leukopenia <4000/μL

Respiratory rate or ABG showing

Tachypnea (>20 breaths per minute) or partial pressure of CO2 less than 32 mmHg, respectively.

Heart rate

Tachycardia (>90 breaths per minute)

 

Blood culture (Option A) is performed to check for sepsis. If SIRS is left untreated, it can progress to sepsis, indicated by a positive blood culture in addition to SIRS.

 

Urine culture (Option B) and Urine routine microscopy (Option C) can also be helpful in management, but they are not included in the criteria for SIRS.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male with malnutrition and alcoholic liver disease presents with increasing abdominal distension, shortness of breath, fever, and significant weight loss. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count greater than 250/μL. Which of the following statements about this condition are true?

 

1. Ascitic fluid appears transparent

2. Most commonly caused by Escherichia coli

3. Cefotaxime can be used for treatment

4. Norfloxacin administration may help to prevent it
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

In this scenario, a malnourished patient with a history of alcoholic liver disease presents with ascites, fever, and ascitic fluid showing a neutrophil count greater than 250/μL, indicating a diagnosis of Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP), with the ascitic fluid appearing turbid due to pus.

Description

A severe complication of ascites, characterised by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intra-abdominal source.

Causative organism
  • Escherichia coli (most common) and other gut bacteria (Statement 2)
  • Gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus)

Source of infection

  

Clinical features
  • Worsening of ascites
  • Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Increase in abdominal girth
  • Encephalopathy

Diagnosis

Ascitic fluid analysis shows:

  • Turbid appearance (Statement 1)
  • Neutrophil count >250/μL
  • Culture and gram satins reveal the causative organisms

Management

IV 3rd generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime) for 5 days (Statement 3)

Prevention

  • Paracentesis within 12 hours of hospital admission
  • Norfloxacin administration (cirrhotic patients with an episode of SBP) (Statement 4)
  • Quinolone antibiotic prophylaxis (recurrent episodes of SBP in variceal bleeding).

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease is scheduled for a procedure as depicted in the image below. What is the name of the procedure?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Paracentesis

 

Explanation:

  • In this case, the patient with a history of congestive heart failure, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease is undergoing Paracentesis (the removal of fluid from the abdominal cavity), as shown in the image.
  • It is a bedside procedure in which a needle or small catheter is inserted transcutaneously to extract ascitic fluid from the peritoneal cavity.
  • Site: Left lower quadrant
  • Procedure:
    • The needle is inserted (USG guided) at a 45-degree angle using the Z-track technique (minimise leakage following the procedure).

  • Advance the needle slowly through the abdominal wall until you feel a pop or loss of resistance, indicating entry into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Both diagnostic (microscopic examination, cytology, gram stain, culture, and sugar and protein values) and therapeutic aspiration were done.
  • Interpretation:
    • Secondary peritonitis: Low sugar values, high LDH values
    • Pancreatic aetiology: Raised amylase
    • Biliary tract perforation: Dark brown fluid

Pericardiocentesis (Option A) is a medical procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pericardial cavity for therapeutic and diagnostic purposes.

  • It is typically performed in conditions like cardiac tamponade.

Thoracentesis (Option B) is a medical procedure that involves inserting a needle or catheter into the pleural space of the chest to remove fluid or air for diagnostic or therapeutic reasons.

  • It is typically performed in cases of pleural effusion, which can be caused by conditions such as lung carcinoma, cirrhosis, or tuberculosis.

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (Option D) is used to assess intra-abdominal bleeding, typically in trauma cases, not for chronic fluid accumulation like ascites.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female with chronic alcoholism, hepatitis C, and hypertension presents with abdominal distension, shortness of breath while lying flat, and fatigue. Ultrasound shows splenomegaly and an increased amount of peritoneal fluid. What are the expected serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) and ascitic protein levels in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ≥1.1 g/dL and <2.5 g/dL

 

Explanation:

  • The patient likely has ascites due to portal hypertension, commonly associated with cirrhosis from chronic alcoholism and hepatitis C.
  • In such cases, the serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically ≥1.1 g/dL, indicating portal hypertension.
  • The ascitic protein level is usually <2.5 g/dL, reflecting low protein transudative fluid associated with cirrhosis.
  • The SAAG reflects hepatic sinusoidal pressure and correlates with the hepatic venous pressure gradient, calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin from the serum albumin (there is no effect of diuresis).
  • Interpretations:
    • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL: Portal hypertension (ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids)
      • Ascitic protein level ≥2.5 g/dL: Hepatic sinusoids are normal (allows passage of protein)
      • Ascitic protein level <2.5 g/dL: Hepatic sinusoids are damaged and scarred (no passage of protein)
    • SAAG <1.1 g/dL: Ascites is not related to portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with chronic liver disease, hepatitis C, and diabetes presents to the emergency department with worsening abdominal distension, shortness of breath, and fatigue. His swelling has worsened despite cutting sodium intake and increasing diuretics, and a fluid thrill is noted on examination. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Propranolol

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes refractory ascites that is unresponsive to sodium restriction and increased diuretics.
  • Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, is contraindicated as it can reduce cardiac output and worsen outcomes by negatively affecting hemodynamics.

 

Management of Ascites

  • Mild ascites: Sodium restriction in diet
  • Moderate ascites
    • Sodium restriction in diet
    • Diuretics:
      • Spironolactone (maximum dose: 400mg)
      • Furosemide (maximum dose 160mg)
  • Refractory ascites (A significant amount of ascites, despite adherence to a low-sodium diet and diuretic therapy)
    • Amiloride (diuretic) (Option B)
    • Midodrine (alpha-1 agonist, vasoconstrictor) (Option C): Vasoconstriction of splanchnic artery
    • Clonidine (alpha-2 agonist, vasoconstrictor) (Option A)
    • Beta-blockers are contraindicated in refractory ascites (increase mortality) (Option D)

  • Adverse effects:
    • Spironolactone: Gynaecomastia (painful)
    • TIPS (transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt): Hepatic encephalopathy.
    • LVP (large volume paracentesis): Asterixis

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with chronic hepatitis and alcohol use presents with abdominal distension, discomfort, shortness of breath, and a weight gain of 5 kg over two weeks. Physical examination reveals thrombocytopenia, splenomegaly, and ascites. With approximately 120 mL of peritoneal fluid, which physical examination sign is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Puddle sign

 

Explanation:

  • With small volumes of ascitic fluid (120 mL), the puddle sign is the most detectable indicator, assessed in the sitting position.
  • The fluid thrill and shifting dullness require larger volumes to be reliably observed.
  • Thus, the puddle sign is the most significant finding in this case.

 

  • Ascites is defined as an accumulation of free fluid in the peritoneal cavity.
  • Normal peritoneal fluid is nil.
    • For females, peritoneal fluid can be 10-20 ml during the mid-ovulatory cycle.

 

Clinical manifestations

  • Initially asymptomatic
  • Approximately 1-2 litres of fluid show signs and symptoms, including:
    • Abdominal distension, discomfort, pain.
    • Weight gain (sudden)
    • Nausea, vomiting
    • Respiratory distress having shortness of breath, dyspnea
    • Edema of body parts
    • Everted umbilicus (due to an increase in ascitic fluid)
  • Clinical signs:
  • Puddle sign (Peritoneal fluid >100ml) (Option C)
    • The puddle sign detects small amounts of fluid in the abdomen.
    • In a sitting position, tapping the abdomen produces a distinct sound over fluid, indicating ascites.

  • Shifting dullness (peritoneal fluid >500ml) (Option B)
    • In a supine position, a healthcare provider percusses the abdomen to identify dullness (fluid) and resonance (air).
    • When the patient turns to one side, the fluid shifts, causing dullness to move to the dependent side and resonance to appear on the upper side, indicating ascitic fluid.

  • Fluid thrill or fluid wave test (Option A)
    • The fluid thrill is a sign of large abdominal fluid volumes (more than 1.5 Liters).
    • It occurs when a provider taps one side of the abdomen while feeling the opposite, creating a wave indicating ascites.
  • Hepatic hydrothorax
    • Fluid from the abdomen, usually due to cirrhosis, accumulates in the pleural cavity, typically on the right side, causing shortness of breath and chest discomfort.
  • Abdominal compartment syndrome (intra-abdominal hypertension) can occur if the pressure due to ascites is more than 25 mm Hg.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with progressive fatigue, abdominal distension, and worsening jaundice over the past three months. Examination reveals ascites, spider angiomata, and palmar erythema. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes with a significantly elevated AST/ALT ratio, and an ultrasound indicates a nodular liver. What role do kupffer cells play in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Induce cytokine production.

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests alcoholic cirrhosis, indicated by symptoms, an elevated AST/ALT ratio, and nodular liver on ultrasound.
  • Kupffer cells, activated by alcohol metabolites and reactive oxygen species, release pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α, interleukins), which stimulate hepatic stellate cells, leading to fibrosis and micronodular cirrhosis.
  • ALD presents as micronodular cirrhosis in the early stages, which may progress to a mixed pattern of micronodular and macronodular cirrhosis in the later stages.
  • Perivenular/pericellular (chicken wire) fibrosis can be observed in the early-stage histopathology of ALD.

Pathogenesis of Alcoholic Cirrhosis:

  • Enzymes that help in metabolising alcohol in the liver:
    • Cytosolic ADH,
    • Microsomal ethanol oxidising system (MEOS)
    • Peroxisomal catalase
  • Alcohol is metabolised to acetaldehyde by cytosolic alcohol dehydrogenase, which will cause reactive oxygen species to contribute to liver cell damage. (Option C)
  • In chronic alcohol consumption,
    • There is reduced fatty acid oxidation and lipoprotein secretion, leading to increased fatty acid uptake, which causes intracellular accumulation of triglycerides. (Option B)
    • The MEOS pathway activates CYP2E1, resulting in increased production of reactive oxygen species and more acetaldehyde, which is converted to acetate by aldehyde dehydrogenase. (Option A)
  • Peroxisomal catalase protects cells from oxidative stress and maintains cellular integrity by neutralising effect.
  • Alcoholic liver disease is a reversible condition if timely intervention occurs and alcohol consumption is discontinued.
  • Alcohol liver disease is the most common condition leading to cirrhosis in India.

 

Causes of Cirrhosis

1. Micronodular Cirrhosis: Characterised by uniform nodules <3 mm in size. Commonly associated with:

  • Alcoholic Liver Disease
  • Chronic Biliary Obstruction and Cholangitis:
    • Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
    • Secondary Biliary Cholangitis
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Non-cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis (NCPF)
 

2. Macronodular Cirrhosis: Characterised by variable nodules >3 mm in size. Associated with:

  • Viral Hepatitis:
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C
  • Hepatitis D
  • Autoimmune Hepatitis
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) (linked to obesity and metabolic syndrome)
  • Wilson Disease
  • Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency
  • Cystic Fibrosis
  • Cryptogenic Cirrhosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of alcohol use and chronic hepatitis presents with abdominal swelling, fatigue, difficulty eating, dark stools, and black vomitus. Examination shows splenomegaly, ascites and dilated veins around the umbilicus. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Doppler ultrasound

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes a patient with chronic hepatitis and alcoholism presenting with splenomegaly, ascites, caput medusae (dilated veins around the umbilicus), hematemesis (dark vomitus), and hematochezia (dark stools).
  • This is diagnosed as portal hypertension, with Doppler ultrasound being the investigation of choice.

 

Investigations of Portal Hypertension:

Investigation

Purpose/Findings

Ultrasonography

Visualises features like splenomegaly and collateral vessels; can identify causes like liver disease or portal vein thrombosis.

Doppler Ultrasound

Investigation of choice to measure pressure gradient.

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) > 5 mm Hg indicates portal hypertension.

Blood Counts (CBC) 

(Option B ruled out)

First biochemical sign is thrombocytopenia (due to hypersplenism).
It also shows leukopenia and anaemia.

Endoscopy

(Option A ruled out)

Used to check for gastro-oesophageal varices.

CT and MRI Scan (Option A ruled out)

Assess the extent of portal vein thrombosis and evaluate hepatic vein patency.

HVPG Measurement

It is rarely performed by interventional radiology to measure hepatic venous pressure gradient directly.

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese female with a history of DVT and recent appendectomy presents with worsening abdominal pain, swelling, fatigue, dark stools, and leg swelling. Examination reveals splenomegaly and findings, which are shown in the image below. Which of the following pathologies is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Portal vein thrombosis

 

Explanation:

The scenario presented, featuring a history of DVT and recent appendectomy, along with splenomegaly, dark stools (hematochezia), and caput medusae (above image), indicates a diagnosis of Portal Hypertension, most likely due to portal vein thrombosis.

 

Causes of Portal Hypertension

Pre-hepatic causes

Hepatic causes

Post-hepatic causes
  • Portal vein thrombosis (OptionC)
  • Splenic vein thrombosis
  • Banti syndrome (characterised by massive splenomegaly of idiopathic origin and is more commonly observed in Japan).
  • Pre-sinusoidal
    • Schistosomiasis
    • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
  • Sinusoidal
    • Cirrhosis
    • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Post-sinusoidal
    • Veno-occlusive disease (hepatic sinusoidal obstruction) (Option B)
    • Radiation
    • Herbal tea
    • Endemic ascites
  • Budd Chiari Syndrome
  • Inferior vena cava webs (Option D)
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Constrictive pericarditis (reduced compliance) (Option A)
  • Severe congestive heart failure

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with worsening abdominal swelling, fatigue, dizziness, increased abdominal size, and loss of appetite. Examination shows a hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) of over 5 mm Hg. What is one of the earliest signs of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Splenomegaly

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s history of chronic alcohol use, along with symptoms like abdominal swelling and an HVPG over 5 mm Hg, suggests portal hypertension, which occurs when there is increased pressure within the portal venous system.
  • Splenomegaly is one of the earliest signs of portal hypertension, caused by congestion in the splenic vein due to increased portal pressure.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Splenomegaly (earliest clinical sign), leading to hypersplenism (Option B)
    • Ascites (increased splenic vein pressure)
      • Puddle sign is positive (When the examiner taps one side of the abdomen while the patient is upright, a wave of fluid can be felt on the opposite side, suggesting fluid accumulation). (Option A)
      • Shifting dullness (When a patient lies supine, the examiner percusses for dullness to indicate fluid. Turning the patient to one side causes the fluid to shift, making the dull area resonant, which confirms free fluid presence).
      • Fluid thrill (Tapping one side of the abdomen while placing a hand on the opposite side; if a wave of fluid is felt, it suggests free fluid in the cavity)
    • Esophageal varices (pressure of >12 mmHg)
      • Coffee ground vomitus (coffee ground like black vomit due to hematemesis) (Option C)

Portal Hypertension:

  • Portal hypertension is defined as the elevation of the hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) to more than 5 mmHg.
  • Mechanism:
    • Increase in resistance of blood flow within the portal vein.
    • Increased splanchnic blood (vasodilation in the splanchnic vascular bed)..
  • Black stools (hematozhezia)
  • Rectal haemorrhoids.

 

Portosystemic (portocaval) collaterals:

  • Anastomosis between the portal and systemic venous systems creates routes of collateral circulation in cases of portal obstruction.
  • These include:

 

Site

Tributaries of portal vein

Tributaries of systemic vein

Associated Clinical Condition

Esophagus (lower end)

Left gastric vein

Esophageal veins

Esophageal varices (esophageal veins)

Rectum (lower end)

Superior rectal vein

Middle and inferior rectal veins

Rectal haemorrhoids

Umbilicus

Paraumbilical vein

Above:

  • Superior epigastric vein
  • Lateral thoracic vein
 

Below:

  • Superficial epigastric vein
  • Inferior epigastric vein
 

Sides:

  • Posterior intercostal and lumbar vein

Caput medusae: Dilated veins present around the umbilicus. (Option D)

 

NOTE:

Dilated veins may also be present exclusively above (superior vena cava thrombosis) or below (inferior vena cava thrombosis) the umbilicus.

Abdominal wall (posterior)

Splenic vein

Left renal vein

-

Bare area of liver

Portal radicles

Diaphragmatic vein

Not seen with the naked eye

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with chronic hepatitis presents with fatigue, mild abdominal discomfort, decreased appetite, and occasional jaundice over the past few months but denies significant weight loss or night sweats. A liver biopsy showed fibrosis with expansion of most portal zones and occasional bridging. What Metavir fibrosis stage does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) F2

 

Explanation:

  • The Metavir fibrosis scoring system categorises stage F2 as fibrosis characterised by the expansion of most portal zones and occasional bridging.
  • Fibrosis extent in liver biopsies is usually assessed using the METAVIR or Ishak scales.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) presents for routine follow-up. She reports mild fatigue but denies significant abdominal pain or jaundice. On examination, she has no stigmata of chronic liver disease. The physician wants to assess the degree of liver fibrosis. Which of the following is the best non-invasive test to evaluate liver stiffness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Transient elastography

 

Explanation:

Transient elastography, also called fibroscan, uses a specialised ultrasound device to measure liver stiffness by emitting a series of low-frequency vibrations (or shear waves) into the liver.

 

Non-invasive investigations for Cirrhosis

Fibrotest
  • This test assesses specific blood markers to determine cirrhosis,
  • Blood markers:
    • Bilirubin
    • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT)
    • Haptoglobin
    • Apolipoprotein A
    • α2 - Macroglobulin,

Serum electrophoresis

In chronic liver disease, this shows decreased albumin and elevated γ Globulin.

Live function test
  • LFTs are commonly used for screening liver health.
  • In chronic hepatitis, both ALT and AST are elevated, with ALT typically greater than AST (ALT > AST).
  • These tests also evaluate vital parameters such as bilirubin and albumin to assess liver function.

 

Computed Tomography (Option A) can provide detailed images of liver morphology and help identify lesions; it does not measure liver stiffness directly.

  • Its primary use is in detecting structural abnormalities rather than evaluating fibrosis.

 

Ultrasound (Option B) is used as an initial investigation.

  • It provides information on liver morphology and assesses complications like portal hypertension.
  • It can provide general information about liver conditions but lacks the specificity for assessing fibrosis levels.

 

Magnetic resonance imaging (Option C) is useful for visualising liver anatomy and detecting lesions; however, like CT scans, it does not directly measure liver stiffness.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female with a history of chronic hepatitis C and cirrhosis presents with increasing abdominal distension, jaundice, and fatigue. On examination, she has ascites and spider nevi. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin levels, low albumin, and elevated liver enzymes. All of the following are criteria for Child-Pugh score classification except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) AST/ALT

 

Explanation:

The Child-Pugh classification is employed to assess the severity of liver disease, predict prognosis for liver cirrhosis, and determine a patient's eligibility for liver transplantation, using a scoring system that incorporates parameters such as:

  • Bilirubin
  • INR
  • Albumin
  • Ascites
  • Hepatic encephalopathy

It does not include liver enzymes like AST/ALT under the criteria.

  • The Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class is determined by summing the scores for each parameter.
  • Category A: 5-6 (Compensated cirrhosis)
  • Category B: 7-9 (Decompensated cirrhosis)
  • Category C: > 10
  • The Child-Pugh score has inherent bias related to ascites and encephalopathy, potentially failing to reflect their severity accurately.
  • This limitation is reduced in the MELD scoring system.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and a Child-Pugh score of 10. Which scoring system is most appropriate for assessing his mortality risk related to liver disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MELD score

 

Explanation:

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) system assesses the severity of chronic liver disease and predicts survival, particularly in patients with cirrhosis.

  • The parameters are
    • Serum bilirubin
    • INR
    • Serum creatinine
  • Recent modifications have been made to enhance its accuracy by adding new parameters to the existing ones, like
    • Serum sodium
    • Need for hemodialysis
  • The range of the score is 6 to 40
  • Liver transplant should be planned before the MELD score reaches 20, as mortality rates increase by 2.5 times beyond this threshold.
  • A higher score increases the chances of being listed for an orthotopic liver transplant.

Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) score is used for children. The parameters used are (Option A)

  • Bilirubin
  • INR
  • Albumin
  • Age
  • Growth failure

 

Rockall risk score (Option B) determines the severity and predicts mortality in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Parameters are

  • Age
  • Heart rate
  • Blood pressure
  • Comorbidities
  • Endoscopic findings
  • History of recent haemorrhage

 

Forest classification system (Option C) can be used to describe the appearance of the ulcer and the risk of bleeding or rebleeding in patients with peptic ulcers.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis presents with increased fatigue, and examination reveals multiple vascular lesions on the skin. His liver function tests show significant elevations in AST and ALT. What is the primary pathophysiological mechanism responsible for the formation of these lesions in cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased vascularity due to estrogen

Explanation:

  • The image depicts spider nevi, vascular lesions with a central arteriole and radiating small vessels, commonly seen in cirrhosis.
  • Impaired liver function reduces estrogen metabolism, leading to increased estrogen levels, vasodilation, and increased vascularity, which form small, dilated blood vessels.
  • Spider nevi typically appear on the skin's surface in areas the superior vena cava supplies, such as the face, neck, and upper body.
  • They can also be observed in conditions like pregnancy and rheumatoid arthritis.


 

Clinical signs & symptoms of Cirrhosis

Vague symptoms
  • Abdominal pain (in the right upper quadrant)
  • Fever
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia

Palmar erythema

It is characterised by reddening of the palms due to increased estrogen levels from impaired liver function, which leads to vasodilation and increased blood flow and serves as an important clinical indicator of liver dysfunction.

Dupuytren's contracture

It happens due to thickening and shortening of the palmar fascia. It can start on the ring finger and involve the little finger.

Clubbing
  • Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) can be released, leading to tissue proliferation at the base of the nail. (Option C)
  • This results in a bulbous appearance, and it is not very specific as can be seen in other conditions.

Parotid enlargement

Especially in alcoholic cirrhosis, due to fat deposition in parotid glands, bilateral parotid enlargement can be appreciated.


 

Testicular atrophy
  • This can result from a combination of increased estrogen, decreased testosterone production and altered hormonal regulation
  • Other manifestations in male patients:
    • Gynecomastia,
    • Decreased body hair
    • Muscle wasting.

Jaundice

This occurs due to the liver's impaired ability to process and excrete bilirubin, resulting in its accumulation in the bloodstream.

Kayser–Fleischer rings

Seen in cirrhosis caused by Wilson’s disease, they are greenish-brown deposits of copper that form in the cornea due to affected copper metabolism.

Asterixis

It is flapping tremors of the hand commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy.

Caput medusae

It is the appearance of engorged superficial veins on the abdominal wall and is a clinical sign of portal hypertension often seen in cirrhosis. (Option A)

 

Chronic hypoxia (Option B) can lead to various systemic changes and conditions like clubbing or cyanosis, but it does not typically cause spider naevi, which is associated with hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with chronic hepatitis C presents with severe fatigue, confusion, and increasing abdominal girth. Examination reveals jaundice, asterixis, and bilateral oedema. Laboratory tests show elevated bilirubin, transaminases, prolonged prothrombin time, and thrombocytopenia. An endoscopy shows the presence of non-bleeding varices. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Decompensated cirrhosis

 

Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario provided, the most likely diagnosis is decompensated cirrhosis with portal hypertension, leading to the development of non-bleeding varices.

 

Decompensated cirrhosis:

  • Patients developing complications due to cirrhosis are considered to have decompensated cirrhosis.
  • Prognosis of patients with this condition is poor.
  • Complications of cirrhosis:
    • Ascites, variceal bleed, jaundice
    • Splenomegaly
    • Portal HTN
    • Coagulopathy
    • Bacterial peritonitis
    • Hepatic encephalopathy
    • Hepatorenal syndrome
    • Hepatopulmonary syndrome

 

Compensated cirrhosis:

  • It is the early stage of cirrhosis, where the liver is significantly damaged yet still performs most essential functions.
  • Patients often remain asymptomatic or experience only mild symptoms due to the liver's compensatory mechanisms.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Option B) is an inflammatory liver condition caused by excessive alcohol consumption, resulting in jaundice, abdominal pain, and liver dysfunction.

  • While it can lead to cirrhosis, the patient's chronic hepatitis C history is more consistent with decompensated cirrhosis based on the current clinical presentation.

 

Acute liver failure (Option C) is a rapid decline in liver function over days or weeks, usually in individuals without pre-existing liver disease.

  • It can result from acetaminophen overdose, viral hepatitis, drug-induced liver injury, or metabolic disorders.
  • However, the chronic history of hepatitis C does not align with an acute presentation.
